bibl.title: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Philip Showalter Hench, May 1954

div1.p: Lambert describes buildings at Columbia Barracks, and recollects about the people involved and their roles in the yellow fever experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Gustaf E. Lambert to Philip Showalter Hench, May 1954
div1.opener:
Mrs Reed's scrapbook photo
of Y F hospital
Date?
May or June 1954
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
I give you my version of the photograph. First the cottages in Mrs. Reed's
picture could have been the original big buildings, if so, they have been re-
modeled. We had no windows on the north side, no entry way, and steps. North
end of building was on the ground back end eight or ten inches off the ground,
if you were down there while visiting Cuba you no doubt recollect that the
land sloped down towards the river. These houses are standing on level ground
and raised about 18 inches. Inside of building it would have been impossible
to put two beds end to end (not wide enough) so if door had been in center,
bed when placed against west wall would have extended more then half way in
front of door. I kept tub for ice inside door right hand side going in. Could
it be possible buildings have been turned around north end to the west. The
ground then would look as level as shown on picture. Whoever fixed up picture
No. 1 was a master at distortion, death house had one window north, one south,
door to east, and seventy five feet south east, he have it placed longside of
road. Disinfection plant should be placed 50 feet to the east and 30 feet south
we had 4 tents pitched between plant and road for men who broke quarantine and
a tank 4 1/2 or 5 feet high east of tents full of disinfectant where men had to dip
in before undressing. My quarters have one window on each side west, north and
south, door on east leading out on platform between my quarters and plant, door on
west end of plant was single, on east end double, the two windows on west end of
plant is correct, because plenty of air was needed when opening chamber even
after drawing vacuum there was a strong smell of formaldehyde. There were no
windows on east end of building, no door on north side, if there had been, one
would have run against disinfection chamber. Picture shows walk from east of
building 105 (Gen. Truby Book). There were no walks, but a path starting west
of my quarters due south to each of 114, Y. F. Hospt. building is too far apart,
if timber (bridge) had been placed where showing in picture a pile of rocks 4-5
feet high would have to be climbed over in order to get to the grounds. There
are seven distinct buildings or huts on right side shown in picture 4 on left,
but no trees are visible, two big ones, one only about 15 feet from building 105
the other about 50 or 60 further east, south of road. Even the trees one on each
side of railroad cut ought to show if it was a camera picture taken in 1900.
Tree on north side was very small but big enough to show. Picture is cleverly
made, but its made; no camera took the original. Where the remark (Dr. Ames'
quarters) came from I don't know. Dr. Ames never stayed but one whole night
which was the first night Grayham was with us. That night Dr. Ames and I carried
two bedsteads from 115 which had been used by Cuban itch cases to 116, 115 being
littered with paper and rags also had a strong smell of iodine. The Doctors
brought down some blankets, that was the only time Dr. Ames stayed the whole
night, but he came down sometimes several times during the night. After moving
his quarters to Camp Lazear he came in every night between land 3 a.m. And as
for Ames office there was a field table and a chair there but if Dr. Ames kept
any books or papers it was not in 114 or any other building. We had in 114 be-
sides table and chair a jar of epsom salt and a pocket case with two scalpels
and a pair of scissors a telephone was at one time hung in. If Dr. Ames did
any writing he must have done it in his room later at Camp Lazear after he moved
there. I am not certain of exact date but I entered Y. F. Hospt. about 12 days
before Major Kean, I say 12 days Graham was a very sick man “he was the one who
had 92 or 94 percent of albumin in his urine” and it must havd been at least 12
before he got away. So from about June 10, 1900 to March 2, 1901, I lived down
there it was my home. I have never laid claim to being smart or bright, but I
refuse to be considered ignorant, only an ignorant person could have lived down
there over eight months without seeing or noticing if there were 4 or 8 buildings.
There were four while I was there; what was contemplated or intended, of course,
I don't know. We had only one death down there a man from one of the batteries.
I can't remember his name. I can take my dying oath that neither Lazear or
2
Carthwright died down there. The same statement goes for my saying that Dr. Ames'
sent me up to help with Carroll at the time he “went over the hump”. I thought
at first he was in his own quarters but but must have been in “officers ward” if
that was the place were Ames was later quartered (place is marked with small
inkspot on gable of building 93 in Gen. Truby Book). I am glad I did not take
care of Lazear or Carthwright as they both died. Where they and Dean were at, I
don't know, I've never made a guess. I've been foolish enoughg to think that if
Carroll had been allowed to get out of bed and walk around he might have brought
on black vomit and gone the way Lazear did. Without disrespect for Dr. Pinto
I must say that he has been talking through his hat. How did he know what building
any of the patients occupied. He was never across the railroad cut. Ames was the
Doctor and did not need any help as there never were more than three patients at
one time except when Ames himself was sick and then only for two days, Pinto was not
there then. And it is certain that Dr. Ames would not have allowed any non-immune
to come in there if he knew he had a positive case of yellow fever and to be frank
I don't think Dr. Pinto would have cared to go in there, not at that time. After
three or four had been through the soiled clothing test without getting sick, I
think some men would have dared to come in, but not at the time Dr. Pinto claimed
he had knowledge of the place. I was in there a non-immune but I know Dr. Ames
would not have allowed me to go out of there. He would not even allow me to step
out of the ambulance when he took me out and showed me Camp Lazear where that was
built. Andrus was no sicker than the rest when he came in. His sickness was
brought on by not being watched, unlimited water was given and no urine passed, then
later when carbuncle developed that gave Andrus another bad spell, why he was not
put in with Folk and Forbes I don't know except it was the Doctor's first patient
and exclusive one but why he did not put him in 114 and leave the woman where they
were I don't know. He was the boss for the time being and did as it pleased him.
I told Gen. Truby in one of my letters that it was Pinto who took Dr. Ames' place
that was wrong, but Andrus suggested that name. If you will take the copies of
Andrus' letters that is still in your possession look in lower corner left side
third or fourth line from bottom, from word Doctor there is a line drawn with pencil
to clean part of paper and the name Pinto is written there is where I got the name
Pinto from. Later I received from Hanbury the group picture (Gen. Truby's book
page 155). I saw then the mistake Dr. Pinto was a well built heavy set man. Dr. Ames
substitute was anemic looking, wearing black full beard. Patients in Y.F. Hospt. did
not need any toilet, they were cleaned and when admitted from there on nothing but
ice and water two days after fever went down or when temperature had been normal two
days they were started on two ounces of milk. They generally left a day or two after
getting up. Your paper Mentions Moran in 115 and Folk in 115, there were 4 patients
between Moran and Folks all in 115. I don't know if I heard Dr. Ames say it or if
I have dreamed it: “Ice and water for a week or ten days and live, or beef steak and
french fry today and die tomorrow.” I wish I had kep a day book and marked down
names and dates. Things I've actually been doing and things I have seen I remember
but what I've heard and read I admit some have slipped my mind. Pictures 2,3,4,
are like 1 not photographs. They show walks all over where there wasn't any but
the only real layed out walk in the hospital the camera missed, the crushed stone
walk between the officers quarters and the wards (See Gen. Truby's book page 76).
Five and six are right except for Y.F. Hospt. 8 buildings where it should be 4. I'VE
told what I saw and what I did. I have not added or withheld anything. It would-
n't do me any good to tell a falsehood because I expect no favor or consideration
for work I did, at least not for work between June and December. But after the
guinea pigs started to come in that's another thing, I know that Major Reed could
have reported success in the work with one less to take soiled clothing test but
had to be some one to care for the ones that took sick. I also know that Major Reed
would have figured the same way if he had been alive. In Gen. Truby's book page 81
it says Lambert was a non-immune and he and other non-immune attendants -- if there
were other non-immune attendants why wasn't their names mentioned? The fact is
that both Mrs. Gillen and Lottie Cook were immunes, that's why they had been hired.
3
They had one patient (Andrus), How they cared for him the letter copies you now
have explains better than I can tell. I have tried in Congress for recognition
in 1940 both Committees of the House, also the Senate recognized the Justice of
my claim but pressure was brought to bear on my Congressman and he let bill lay
and diet in Committee. I might try again. Its a shame to have wasted so much
paper in saying so little but I have done the best I know.

Lazear died
Sept 25?
Lambert wasnt available
& to Truby
But Lambert didn't nurse Lazear Miss Leur's
helped nurse him & she says he did die in the
Y F huts

closer.seg:
PS: Please return the two thin paper copies of letters, Andrus sent Senators'
Lewis and Connelly or Shepperd. Both maps are good, Morgue should be a little
further from the road then disinfection plant. Y.F. Hospt. had at one time been
fenced in. 12 or 15 feet from S.E. corner of Building 116 was an 8 foot post
with several strands of barb wire. The longest one laying toward La Playa. I
suppose Cubans had stolen the rest. I think you, Dr. Hench, I think you will give
Ames credit for his excellent work. I think you will mention that he had yellow
fever himself (something that has never been shown in print). I liked Dr. Ames,
I have been an employee for over 60 years. He was my best boss. I know Ames
liked me as a Man. He was a Mason and recommended me as a member of the fraternity!
Sergeant Ryan, patient in 115, was a member of committee investigating my fitness
for membership and the one why string was used to keep me awake. This information
is not for your book. for whom the
Respt. Lambert
Later:
Please disregard all mention of Andrus copies when puting letter back in same
envelop in which it came I found your personal letter also copies I received
from Andrus. I hadn't seen them or noticed when they came I am sorry Doctor
that I can't convince you about the number of buildings we had at the Y. F. Hospt.
It resolves itself into two things, either I was at that time so stupid and
dullwitted that I couldn't tell the difference between four and eight or I would
be lying now. To the first I answer, I refuse to be considered to ever having
been in that condition, to the second I answer So help me God I am telling the
truth, no good could come to me by telling a falsehood or harm to any one else.
I am telling just what I saw while living down there between middle of June and
March 2nd card 5 is a surveyors map and correct, card 6 is a draftsmans copy,
cards 1,2,3,4, O marked the backs, pardon) is made uup and frauds of camera
pictures only, what was there would have showed. Take hut 113 for example, if
entrance had faced toward the Gen. Hospt. it had a toilet either in front or along-
side the entrance. There was no toilet, huts 113 and 114 faced away from and build
ings 115 and 116 faced toward the Gen. Hospt. All my meals carried down from Miss
Lottie and Mrs. Gillen got theirs from their mess. The little diet patients
received came from diet kitchen hospt. boys could leave as soon as dressed. When any-
one was transferred while I was in the service the order was made in triplicate,
one kept in place from where he was sent one copy was sent to Washington Adj. Gen.
Office which was the permanent record and one copy sent to place where going,
Officers I suppose brought their copy with them, men had theirs sent after.
Mrs. Ames had the copy given Ames but it was no good except it could be duplicated
or verified by one from the Adj. Gen. Office. You must believe me Doctor when I tell
you that attempts have been made since 1929 to get a copy of Gen. order 83 from
Washington but without success. Senator Shepperd, the Congressman before Thormason
Thormason, later Brunby all got the same answers-no such order. I have Ames'
(4
service record. Its not mentioned. If I stated that Ames was a major in the
regular army I made an unforgiveable mistake because Ames could. never have been
a regular Army officer. It was not in him. All contract doctors entered the
service as A.A.S.V. and attained higher rank by professional ability but the
difference between U.S. Officers and U.S.A.V. was as night and day. The feeling
of regular army officers toward Vol. officers was nicely expressed in a letter
to you “copy of which Mrs. Ames showed me” Vol. was neither flesh, fish, or salt
herring. Gen. Truby a sends to it on page 67 in the case of Gen. Wood it was not
age. It was the Vol. and his quick advancement. Maj. Kean was only a Capt. of
the regular army at that time he held the rank of Maj. Vol. for reason of better
pay or prestige, but he had the rank of regular U.S.A. Capt. for a backing.
Dear Dr. Hench:
I know you are after the true record. I have given you what I know after living
at Quemadas for 15 months, over eight months of the time below railroad out. I
don't think I could dictate to a stenographer. If you have occasion to write
again please tell girl to use good carbon paper, if original letter, blacker
ribbon. Even with two reading glasses one in front of the other I had to guess
part of your letter.
Very respt. yours.
Gust. E. Lambert
